Overview: A common dermatological condition characterized by blackheads (comedones) and mild to severe inflammation on the chin and lower lip.
Symptoms: Black dots, pimples, crusts, redness, swelling, pustules, hair loss; may be itchy or sore in more severe cases.
Causes: Follicular obstruction from excess keratin; bacterial infection; plastic food bowls; poor grooming; stress; allergies; hormonal imbalance.
Prevention Tips:
- Replace plastic dishes with stainless steel, ceramic, or glass and wash daily.
- Maintain regular cleanliness and grooming.
- Monitor stress and manage any allergic or hormonal triggers.
Approved Treatment and Protocols:
1. Cleanse daily with benzoyl peroxide or chlorhexidine wipes/shampoos.
2. Clip hair around lesions for hygiene.
3. Topical antibiotics (mupirocin, clindamycin).
4. Systemic antibiotics, corticosteroids, isotretinoin in severe cases 
5. Omega‑3 fatty acid supplements to improve skin health.
Feline vs Canine: Works similarly in both species, but feline acne is localized to the chin and lower lip.

Overview: Inflammatory skin disease triggered by environmental (atopic) or food allergens.
Symptoms: tchy, red, inflamed skin, chewing, licking, scratching, commonly affecting face, paws, ears, belly.
Causes: Pollen, dust mites, mold, food proteins.
Prevention Tips:
- Allergen avoidance.
- Hypoallergenic diet trials.
- Regular grooming and control of environmental allergens.
Approved Treatment and Protocols:
- Antihistamines, corticosteroids, immunotherapy.
- Topical soothing shampoos, fatty acid supplementation.
- In severe, chronic cases, oclacitinib or cyclosporine may be used.
Feline vs Canine: Present in both; in cats, often results in eosinophilic granuloma complex. In dogs, typically manifests as atopic dermatitis.

Overview: Chronic, allergic, inflammatory skin disease often seen in cats and dogs.
Symptoms: Chronically itchy and inflamed skin.
Causes: Environmental allergens (often seasonal).
Prevention Tips:
- Regular baths
- Allergen control
- Diet optimization.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Antihistamines, steroids, immunotherapy, biologics, fatty acid supplementation.
Feline vs Canine: Comparable in both; cats may develop nodules (eosinophilic granuloma complex).

Overview: Severe hypersensitivity to flea saliva.
Symptoms: Row of red bumps near the fleas; intense itching and self-trauma.
Causes: Flea bites—often 1 bite triggers severe reaction.
Prevention Tips: Year-round flea control via approved topical or oral preventives; regular combing.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Flea elimination, steroids/antihistamines for itching, antibiotics for secondary infections.

Overview: Also known as “scabby dermatitis,” denoted by multiple small crusts.
Symptoms: Tiny scabs, papules, often beneath insulating fur coat.
Causes: Allergies (flea, food, contact), parasites (fleas, mites), infections.
Prevention Tips: Address underlying cause; consistent parasite control.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Steroids, antibiotics, antiparasitics, soothing shampoos; treat allergies and parasites.
Feline vs Canine: Mainly feline; not typical in dogs.

Overview: Fungal infection, not actual worm.
Symptoms: Circular lesions with hair loss, scaling, slight itching.
Causes: Microsporum or Trichophyton species; contagious across species & to humans.
Prevention Tips: Quarantine infected animals; disinfect environment.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Topical antifungals (lime sulfur dips, miconazole), + systemic itraconazole or terbinafine.

Overview: Oily, greasy swelling on the tail, caused by overactive sebaceous glands.
Symptoms: Greasy hair, localized alopecia, odor.
Causes: Hyperplasia of tail glands, often hormonally driven.
Prevention Tips: No specific prevention.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Topical keratolytics and seborrheic shampoos, in severe cases surgical gland removal; address hormonal drivers if identifiable.

Overview: Group of lesions (rodent ulcer, indolent ulcer, eosinophilic plaque) often allergic in nature.
Symptoms: Ulcers (lips normally), plaques, nodules.
Causes: Likely allergy-mediated (flea, food, atopic).
Prevention Tips: Allergy management.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Corticosteroids, antibiotics if infected, address underlying allergies, possibly immunosuppressive therapy.

Overview: Feline Leukemia Virus impairs immunity and predisposes cats to skin infections/neoplasia.
Symptoms: Chronic lesions, non-healing wounds, unusual growths.
Causes: FeLV infection.
Prevention Tips: FeLV vaccination, indoor lifestyle, FeLV testing on new cats.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Supportive care, antibiotics, antivirals if available; often guarded prognosis.

Overview: Localized pockets of pus under skin due to trauma.
Symptoms: Painful swelling, fever, lethargy; sometimes draining tracts.
Causes: Bite or scratch wounds, often from fighting.
Prevention Tips: Neutering to reduce roaming/fighting, supervise outdoor exposure.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Vet drainage, flushing, antibiotics, analgesics, possible sedated/lanced treatment.

Overview: Similar in mechanism to feline acne, resulting in pimples and inflammation often located near the lips or chin.
Symptoms: Pimples, swelling, redness, possible crusts in the affected area.
Causes: Follicular obstruction; bacterial overgrowth (e.g., Staphylococcus); trauma from licking, collars, or plastic bowls; genetic predisposition (common in Boxers, Bulldogs, Great Danes, Weimaraners, Mastiffs, Rottweilers, Dobermans); possible allergies.
Prevention Tips: Keep chin area clean; avoid plastic bowls—use ceramic or stainless steel; improve grooming habits; monitor for underlying allergies.
Approved Treatment and Protocols:
Clean area with benzoyl peroxide or chlorhexidine.
Use topical antibiotics; in severe cases, systemic antibiotics.
A 4–6 week course often needed; culture and sensitivity if relapse occurs
Feline vs Canine: Very similar overall; acne is less common in dogs than cats.

Overview: Pruritic dermatitis caused by environmental or food sensitivities.
Symptoms: Itchy, red skin; chewing, scratching; commonly on ears, paws, belly, and face.
Causes: Pollen, dust mites, mold, food proteins.
Prevention Tips:
Avoid allergens when possible.
Try hypoallergenic diets.
Maintain regular grooming and clean environment.
Approved Treatment and Protocols:
Antihistamines, corticosteroids for relief.
Allergen-specific immunotherapy.
Topical shampoos and fatty acid supplements.
Chronic atopy may involve oclacitinib (Apoquel) or cyclosporine (Atopica).
Feline vs Canine: Dogs typically manifest allergic dermatitis; cats may show eosinophilic granulomas or miliary dermatitis.

Overview: Chronic itching and inflammation due to environmental allergens.
Symptoms: Persistent itchiness, redness, possible secondary skin thickening, hot spots.
Causes: Pollens, molds, dust mites; genetic predisposition.
Prevention Tips:
Frequent baths to remove allergens.
Minimize allergen exposure.
Dietary optimization to support skin.
Approved Treatment and Protocols:
Antihistamines, corticosteroids.
Immunotherapy (shots or drops).
Biologic therapy (e.g., Cytopoint).
Fatty acid supplementation.
Feline vs Canine: Both species affected; biologics more commonly used in dogs.

Overview: Parasitic infection caused by Demodex mites; may be juvenile (localized) or adult (generalized).
Symptoms: Hair loss, redness, lesions, pustules, primarily on face, ears, paws.
Causes: Overgrowth of Demodex due to immature or compromised immunity; juvenile onset often resolves; adult onset is more serious.
Prevention Tips: Maintain general health and parasite prevention; genetic screening in breeding.
Approved Treatment and Protocols:
Localized cases may self-resolve or use topical moxidectin/imidacloprid.
Generalized cases: weekly amitraz dips or oral ivermectin/milbemycin, isoxazolines (fluralaner, afoxolaner, sarolaner).
Treat secondary bacterial infection with antibiotics.
Feline vs Canine: Severity and treatment similar, but dogs exhibit both localized and generalized forms frequently.

Overview: Rapid-onset, painful, moist, bacterial skin infection stemming from self-trauma and moisture.
Symptoms: Red, moist, oozing lesion with hair loss and pain; typically single site.
Causes: Minor irritants (bites, damp fur), allergies, poor grooming, curiosity licking.
Prevention Tips:
Keep coat dry.
Maintain flea control.
Groom regularly.
Offer mental stimulation to reduce licking.
Approved Treatment and Protocols:
1. Clip fur around lesion and clean with chlorhexidine or mild antiseptic.
2. Apply topical antibacterial and corticosteroid sprays or ointments.
3. Use 1% hydrocortisone creams or astringents (Domeboro).
4. Administer oral antibiotics (e.g., cephalexin for ~2 weeks) if infection is deeper.
5. Use corticosteroids (prednisone 0.5 mg/kg short course) to reduce inflammation.
6. Use an Elizabethan collar or recovery suit to prevent self-trauma.
7. Address underlying cause (allergies, parasites, moisture).
Typical healing in 3–7 days.
Feline vs Canine: Rare in cats; predominantly a canine condition.

Overview: Skin tumors of mast cells with variable behavior—from benign to malignant.
Symptoms: Firm, sometimes itchy or red lumps on the skin.
Causes: Likely genetic; some breeds predisposed; exact etiology unclear.
Prevention Tips: No known prevention.
Approved Treatment and Protocols:
Surgical removal with clean margins.
Possible chemotherapy or radiation depending on grade/staging.

Overview: Bacterial skin infection—superficial or deep; often secondary to allergies, parasites, hormone issues.
Symptoms: Redness, swelling, pustules, crusts, possible odor or oozing.
Causes: Overgrowth of Staphylococcus and other bacteria due to compromised skin.
Prevention Tips:
Manage underlying allergies and parasites.
Use proper hygiene.
Supplement with omega‑3 fatty acids.
Approved Treatment and Protocols:
Topical antibacterial shampoos/creams (chlorhexidine, benzoyl peroxide).
Systemic antibiotics for deeper infections.

Overview: Contagious fungal skin infection (not a worm) causing round lesions.
Symptoms: Round lesions, hair loss, scaling, occasional itchiness.
Causes: Microsporum or Trichophyton species; zoonotic potential.
Prevention Tips: Quarantine affected pets; disinfect environment; use fungus-killing products.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Topical antifungals (lime sulfur dips, miconazole); systemic itraconazole or terbinafine.

Overview: Extremely contagious parasitic infection by Sarcoptes scabiei mites.
Symptoms: Intense red itchiness, hair loss, sores, thickened skin.
Causes: Infestation from infected animals or environment.
Prevention Tips: Isolate infected pets; treat all in household; maintain regular flea/tick preventives.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Oral or topical ivermectin, selamectin, moxidectin; isoxazolines; topical lime sulfur dips; treat all contacts; clean environment.

Overview: Disorder of skin causing flaking (dry or oily) and greasiness.
Symptoms: Dandruff, greasiness, odor, flaking, itchiness.
Causes: Primary (genetic) or secondary to allergies, infections, endocrine disorder, sebaceous adenitis
Prevention Tips: Manage underlying disease; regular grooming; medicated baths.
Approved Treatment and Protocols: Use medicated shampoos (keratolytic, antifungal, antibacterial); supplement with omega‑3s; treat any primary disease.
